body: Confirmed by one of reporting users this PR makes his life in VSCode much better. Can you merge?

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-5757 (Compile-on-Save drops static initializer)

Removed an unnecessary parameters change of `org.netbeans.modules.debugger.jpda.truffle.source.SourcePosition` constructor, which changed friend API. No API changes are necessary.

Those packages should not be public.

This is no API and may change frequently,
which requires increasing module version frequently,
which causes problems for modules that depend on FlatLaf module
(e.g. upcoming JFormDesigner module).

Adding package `com.formdev.flatlaf.ui` to public package will probably break sigtest running with Java 8:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1771#issuecomment-564956178

BTW FlatLaf JAR should be not checked into Git!

Isn't there a way to make packages accessible to specific other modules? (friends??)

> Isn't there a way to make packages accessible to specific other modules? (friends??)

Yes the friend mechanism might be the right approach, though it might become necessary to split the module as a module can either expose a public api or a friend api, but not both. The other option, if the two modules are hard dependencies for each other are implementation dependencies. An implementation dependency can be declared against every module - in that case the complete module can be accessed, but it will not be possible to combine the module with a different version.

The above should be taken with a grain of salt and validated :-)
PR #2993 already fixes the issue
I need the com.formdev.flatlaf.ui and other packages to public. Used the swingx components on the my project. Isn't there a way? I am currently using the nbm package that I produced.

> I agree that the semantics of actions in configurations are getting more and more complicated.
> 
> Can't we stick to existing API? And just: if project's `ProjectConfigurationProvider != null` and `configurationsAffectAction(action)` and not `ActionProvider.isActionEnabled(action, singleton(configuration))` then don't show the action?
> 
> Why? Because the action is _affected by configurations and currently disabled_ - e.g. not available in current configuration.

This approach is not usable for me.
Because of this condition in gradle's `ConfigurableActionsProviderImpl.findActionProvider`:
```
if (m == null) {
    m = getActionData(GradleExecConfiguration.DEFAULT).getAction(action);
}
```
It defaults to the DEFAULT configuration. And this is exactly what I do not need. It makes sens to add only actions that differ in the configurations.
I must not include debug of continuous mode. And this would add it.
I'm not that experienced in projects, but I did not find an existing API that would suit the intended use-case.

Obsolete; closing.
Good: I've checked this together with [PR-2995](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2995) and it seems to play well together. Code lenses only report 'Run' for Continuous mode to the LSP client.

I added a possibiltiy to disable an action (button **Disable**) and a way how the user can **Restore** the action:
- the Disable customized action will be removed, returning to the provided configuration's defaults (if that default is not 'disable' instruction), or
- the action def for the `default` configuration, if it exists.
This way the user can re-enable `Debug` actions and define whatever behaviour she/he likes in the continuous mode.

![disabled-debug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26788611/122539529-fead3c00-d027-11eb-96a6-618f4208c15a.jpg)
The functionality seems to run fine locally. Once the checks are OK, I'll integrate.

adding do not merge because donation not done

Eric appreciate the comments and I hope none of this comes across wrong...

That is another reason it's still a draft.  

I've been asking and waiting for status on Python donation for close to a year and have yet to receive any feedback.

Given most of the code was available in one form or another (hg repository before decommissioned and maven-ized GitHub versions) it just unclear what specifically is being waited on.

For reference 

- http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/netbeans-dev/202004.mbox/%3cCACkjAxTUEjs4mhskTNvAehQAJH_qFY=UE3bVeXYUcW6f+YPVKg@mail.gmail.com%3e

- http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/netbeans-dev/202012.mbox/%3cCAHw6w1QkiMyBU4hqPkq1MLMc7YbbPxT1AKfjS7ysF-yCkjr-Cw@mail.gmail.com%3e

> Given most of the code was available in one form or another (hg repository before decommissioned and maven-ized GitHub versions) it just unclear what specifically is being waited on.

I can only comment why I will veto merging this:

The Code in the hg repository is CDDL/GPLv2-CPE licensed. Only the owner of the copyright can change the license. The owner in this case is Oracle. The donation process that was done for other modules transfers ownership to the ASF and thus gives it (and as the Apache NetBeans project is part of the ASF "us") the right to change the license.

Large bodies of CDDL/GPLv2-CPE code can't be included in the sourcecode of an ASF project, so this is blocked.

> > Given most of the code was available in one form or another (hg repository before decommissioned and maven-ized GitHub versions) it just unclear what specifically is being waited on.
> 
> I can only comment why I will veto merging this:
> 
> The Code in the hg repository is CDDL/GPLv2-CPE licensed. Only the owner of the copyright can change the license. The owner in this case is Oracle. The donation process that was done for other modules transfers ownership to the ASF and thus gives it (and as the Apache NetBeans project is part of the ASF "hus") the right to change the license.
> 
> Large bodies of CDDL/GPLv2-CPE code can't be included in the sourcecode of an ASF project, so this is blocked.

This is a draft PR so accept it's not ready for merging yet.

See previous email threads quoted previously on this topic which includes much of this sort of concern discussed on the mailing list  

I understand concern with Oracle needing to address the formal donation.  I've been waiting and requesting status for quite some time, but without much luck.  This led me to believe there is either no interest to pursure it further, no one (at Oracle) familiar or actively working it [i.e. Geertjan was spearheading a lot of the past netbean donation effor and is no longer with Oracle, it takes time and money to do necessary activities, etc.], or it just takes a long time to do (even though other dontations seemed to go a lot quicker).  

The thread has input from nb python team (who signed OCAs and/or worked for Oracle at the time) so it seemed like much of the concern about approval from original developed seemed resolved with the final aspect of Oracle donating the code being the last part.  However there was no apparent movement on this front.  

It was suggested in the thread using the netbeans-tools (I did make a fix to the tool in the process) could be used to update the headers to applicable Apache headers to help on code header update aspects.  

It still seems strange that the hg repository was available with the code so not sure why it was accessible here compare to a "donated version" but then again IANAL and I'm sure there are aspects I'm not aware of to consider.  

Given Python is one of the major languages in use in the field now, not having it available in Netbeans is a big hole that I feel needs to be filled which is why I'm pushing this so much.

In the end, to overcome a lot of the above "Conflicting files" I've started another nbpython_integration3 branch for a little cleaner version so this draft PR will likely go away and moved to a new one, but once again, will not raise a PR until such time as it is acceptance.

Isn't that because it's an invalid namespace?

Strictly speaking the `http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0` is an identifier although in a form of URI. The referenced `https://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd` really declares **http://** URI as its `targetNamespace`:
```
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" targetNamespace="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0">
```
so I'd say it's a lucky coincidence that a POM that uses `https://` namespace URI actually validates. Maybe some later authoritative statement from W3C changed that, [but originally](https://www.w3.org/TR/2009/REC-xml-names-20091208/#ns-decl)
> The namespace name, to serve its intended purpose, SHOULD have the characteristics of uniqueness and persistence. It is not a goal that it be directly usable for retrieval of a schema (if any exists)
Also found this, so we're not alone - https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-270998  This should be punted back to Micronaut?

Yes - a namespace does not need to relate to a concrete document. Its the job of the resolver to fetch the right document. NetBeans carries multiple catalogs, that resolve namespaces to actual documents and the built-in resolvers resolve to local documents bundled with netbeans (have a look at the `enterprise/j2ee.dd` and `enterprise/j2ee.ddloaders` modules, which carry the XSDs for the JavaEE deployment descriptors).

A good part of the XSDs has a targetNamespace of:

http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/javaee

It is pure luck, that at that location a list of descriptors is placed, that can be used by humans to download the files.

If the micronaut applications really target the `https...` namespace, they target a different namespace, then maven does itself. I would consider it a bug in micronaut.

I use netbeans on a private network. After upgrading to netbeans 12.4 I can no longer add a java ee server to my war project due to this change since https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/fish/payara/distributions/payara/maven-metadata.xml is not reachable. Is there a work around?

@bdrx312 if you really think that this PR is somehow responsible for anything, you need to make a case for that. Most issue reports on that level can be rejected with a "works for me". You need to describe:

- why do you think this PR is responsible
- what do you observe
- how can it be reproduced

If you can't answer these questions, you won't get help.

Thanks for looking into this. Would it be possible to pull the file from a local file location or from a configured or local maven repo? In netbeans, a user can customize their maven repositories to edit their repository url and add additional repositories. It may be more robust to use the configured maven repository  rather than a hardcoded one.
